user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of thread_main_connection_upgrade:
```c
static void
thread_main_connection_upgrade (struct MHD_Connection *con)
{
#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
  struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle *urh = con->urh;
  struct MHD_Daemon *daemon = con->daemon;

  mhd_assert ( (! MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_ (daemon)) || \
               MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_current_thread_ (con->tid) );
  /* Here, we need to bi-directionally forward
     until the application tells us that it is done
     with the socket; */
  if ( (0 != (daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS)) &&
       MHD_D_IS_USING_SELECT_ (daemon))
  {
    while ( (0 != urh->in_buffer_size) ||
            (0 != urh->out_buffer_size) ||
            (0 != urh->in_buffer_used) ||
            (0 != urh->out_buffer_used) )
    {
      /* use select */
      fd_set rs;
      fd_set ws;
      fd_set es;
      MHD_socket max_fd;
      int num_ready;
      bool result;

      FD_ZERO (&rs);
      FD_ZERO (&ws);
      FD_ZERO (&es);
      max_fd = MHD_INVALID_SOCKET;
      result = urh_to_fdset (urh,
                             &rs,
                             &ws,
                             &es,
                             &max_fd,
                             FD_SETSIZE);
      if (! result)
      {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
        MHD_DLOG (con->daemon,
                  _ ("Error preparing select.\n"));
#endif
        break;
      }
      /* FIXME: does this check really needed? */
      if (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET != max_fd)
      {
        struct timeval *tvp;
        struct timeval tv;
        if (((con->tls_read_ready) &&
             (urh->in_buffer_used < urh->in_buffer_size)) ||
            (daemon->shutdown))
        {         /* No need to wait if incoming data is already pending in TLS buffers. */
          tv.tv_sec = 0;
          tv.tv_usec = 0;
          tvp = &tv;
        }
        else
          tvp = NULL;
        num_ready = MHD_SYS_select_ (max_fd + 1,
                                     &rs,
                                     &ws,
                                     &es,
                                     tvp);
      }
      else
        num_ready = 0;
      if (num_ready < 0)
      {
        const int err = MHD_socket_get_error_ ();

        if (MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_EINTR_ (err))
          continue;
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
        MHD_DLOG (con->daemon,
                  _ ("Error during select (%d): `%s'\n"),
                  err,
                  MHD_socket_strerr_ (err));
#endif
        break;
      }
      urh_from_fdset (urh,
                      &rs,
                      &ws,
                      &es,
                      (int) FD_SETSIZE);
      process_urh (urh);
    }
  }
#ifdef HAVE_POLL
  else if (0 != (daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS))
  {
    /* use poll() */
    struct pollfd p[2];
    memset (p,
            0,
            sizeof (p));
    p[0].fd = urh->connection->socket_fd;
    p[1].fd = urh->mhd.socket;

    while ( (0 != urh->in_buffer_size) ||
            (0 != urh->out_buffer_size) ||
            (0 != urh->in_buffer_used) ||
            (0 != urh->out_buffer_used) )
    {
      int timeout;

      urh_update_pollfd (urh, p);

      if (((con->tls_read_ready) &&
           (urh->in_buffer_used < urh->in_buffer_size)) ||
          (daemon->shutdown))
        timeout = 0;     /* No need to wait if incoming data is already pending in TLS buffers. */
      else
        timeout = -1;

      if (MHD_sys_poll_ (p,
                         2,
                         timeout) < 0)
      {
        const int err = MHD_socket_get_error_ ();

        if (MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_EINTR_ (err))
          continue;
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
        MHD_DLOG (con->daemon,
                  _ ("Error during poll: `%s'\n"),
                  MHD_socket_strerr_ (err));
#endif
        break;
      }
      urh_from_pollfd (urh,
                       p);
      process_urh (urh);
    }
  }
  /* end POLL */
#endif
  /* end HTTPS */
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
  /* TLS forwarding was finished. Cleanup socketpair. */
  MHD_connection_finish_forward_ (con);
  /* Do not set 'urh->clean_ready' yet as 'urh' will be used
   * in connection thread for a little while. */
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function thread_main_connection_upgrade:
#define HAVE_POLL 1
...
#define HAVE_MESSAGES 1
...
#define MHD_D_IS_USING_SELECT_(d) (0==(d->options&(MHD_USE_POLL|MHD_USE_EPOLL)))
...
#define MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_(d) (0!=(d->options&(MHD_USE_INTERNAL_POLLING_THREAD)))
...
#define MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_current_thread_(hndl_id) MHD_thread_ID_is_current_thread_((hndl_id).ID)
...
#define MHD_INVALID_SOCKET (-1)
...
#define MHD_SYS_select_(n, r, w, e, t) select((n),(r),(w),(e),(t))
...
#define MHD_sys_poll_ poll
...
#define MHD_socket_get_error_ (errno)
...
#define MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_EINTR_(err) MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_((err),MHD_SCKT_EINTR_)
...
#define MHD_socket_strerr_(err) strerror((err))
...
void
MHD_DLOG (const struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
          const char *format,
          ...)
{
  va_list va;

  if (0 == (daemon->options & MHD_USE_ERROR_LOG))
    return;
  va_start (va, format);
  daemon->custom_error_log (daemon->custom_error_log_cls,
                            format,
                            va);
  va_end (va);
}
...
#define MHD_connection_finish_forward_(conn) (void)conn
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I selected all code regions that can be conditionally compiled or conditionally executed and therefore are the most likely places to contain unreachable code under some build/runtime configurations: the entire HTTPS_SUPPORT guarded block (which will be omitted if HTTPS_SUPPORT is not defined), the select-based forwarding path and its max_fd gating, and the poll-based forwarding path (inside HAVE_POLL). I also included the error-handling portions that use MHD_socket_get_error_() because they occur in both branches and are candidates for being skipped or never entered depending on configuration/state.

Other code fragments were not listed because they are either trivial declarations/initialisations, final cleanup that is always reached after the conditional HTTPS block (MHD_connection_finish_forward_(con);), or runtime-dependent loops/branches that are not inherently unreachable (their entry depends on daemon->options, urh buffer sizes, or signals). Additionally, HAVE_POLL and HAVE_MESSAGES are defined in the provided configuration, so the corresponding blocks are compiled in and are not inherently unreachable; the fragments above cover the conditional points that could lead to unreachable code under different macro configurations or daemon options. If you want me to narrow investigations to specific lines (for example the MHD_socket_get_error_ macro usage or the max_fd check) I can mark those exact lines separately.
